analytic.title: Brv1 Is Required for Drosophila Larvae to Sense Gentle Touch

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: Highlights d Brv1 is essential for gentle-touch sensation d Brv1 mediates the mechanotransduction of class III da neurons d Brv1 forms a mechanosensitive cation channel d Brv1 amplifies the touch response of NOMPC
In Brief Zhang et al. demonstrate that Brv1 is required for Drosophila larvae to sense gentle touch and mediates the mechanotransduction of class III dendritic arborization neurons.
Electrophysiological analysis reveals that Brv1 forms a stretch-activated cation channel.

Touch sensation is the ability to sense and respond to mechanical stimuli, and it is essential for fundamental behaviors, including harm avoidance, environmental exploration, and social exchange (Lumpkin et al., 2010;Walsh et al., 2015).

The mechanotransduction of touch relies on mechanosensitive ion channels that transform mechanical stimuli into electrical signals in sensory neurons (Delmas et al., 2011;Geffeney and Goodman, 2012;Schafer, 2015;Wu et al., 2017).
Genetic dissection of touch transduction in Drosophila larvae has led to the identification of several candidates that may sense mechanical forces (Kernan et al., 1994;Montell, 2005).
Painless, a TRPA channel subunit expressed in a subset of larval type II multiple dendritic neurons, is involved in mechanical nociception (Tracey et al., 2003).
The DEG/ENaC channel Pickpocket and Drosophila PIEZO (dPIEZO) are essential for noxious mechanosensation in class IV dendritic arborization (da) neurons (Zhong et al., 2010;Kim et al., 2012).
The Drosophila TRPN channel NOMPC (no mechanoreceptor potential C) is highly expressed in class III da neurons and is required for gentle-touch sensation (Yan et al., 2013).
Among these channels, dPIEZO and NOMPC have been shown to form mechanically activated channels with distinct biophysical and pore-related properties.

Although these findings have advanced our knowledge of the physics and physiology of touch sensation, new molecular entities and underlying mechanisms in sensory neurons remain to be identified and characterized to unravel the complexity of touch.
Brv1 is a member of the TRPP (TRP polycystin) subfamily of TRP ion channels and is known for its role in cold sensation in the fly antenna (Gallio et al., 2011).
Brv1 shares sequence homology with the mammalian TRPP2 channels (also known as PKD2).
TRPP2 is a Ca 2+ -permeable cation channel and functions as part of a polycystin receptor-channel complex that senses fluid flow and induces a Ca 2+ signal response (Cantiello, 2004).
These findings suggest a role of TRPP2 in mechanosensation; however, whether Brv1 participates in mechanical responses has remained unclear.
Here we report the role of Drosophila Brv1 in touch sensation.
Behavioral assay and Ca 2+ responses indicated that Brv1 is required for class III da sensory neurons to sense gentle touch.
We further demonstrated that Brv1 confers stretch-activated currents when heterologously expressed in a mammalian expression system and reconstituted into proteoliposomes.
In addition, a co-expression study suggested that Brv1 amplifies the response of NOMPC channels in touch sensation.
These findings demonstrate that Brv1 mediates the gentle-touch response in Drosophila larvae.

div.head: Brv1 Is Required for Mechanotransduction in Larval

p.s: Class III da Neurons that Sense Gentle Touch To determine whether Brv1 mediates mechanotransduction, we examined its role in touch sensation.

The brv1 loss-of-function (LOF) mutant larvae were tested for defects in touch sensation using a previously established behavioral assay, by which the thoracic segments were touched with an eyelash and the gentle-touch responses were scored (Kernan et al., 1994).

The mutant brv1 DEL was generated by the deletion of 92 amino acids (112-204) within the two putative transmembrane helixes predicted by the TMHMM program (Figures S1A and S1B), and brv1 STOP is a previously described nonsense mutant with a stop-codon insertion at Leu563 (Gallio et al., 2011).
We found that both brv1 DEL and brv1 STOP larvae were viable and displayed normal morphology; however, these mutants showed severe defects in their behavioral response to gentle touch.
The gentletouch response scores of brv1 DEL and brv1 STOP larvae were significantly lower than those of the wild-type (WT) (Figure 1A).

The brv1 LOF larvae had a touch score predominantly distributed at the type 0 ''no response,'' in contrast to the type 2 response ''recoil'' for the WT (Figure 1B), implying that Brv1 mediates larval responses to gentle touch.
Previous behavioral studies in Drosophila have identified class III da neurons as the substrates of gentle-touch detection (Yan et al., 2013).

To address the question of whether Brv1 and class III da neurons act interdependently to mediate touch sensation, we targeted brv1 in these neurons using RNAi under the control of a class III da neuron-specific Gal4 driver (19-12-Gal4) and evaluated the larval responses.

The restricted knockdown of Brv1 in class III da neurons resulted in a decrease in the gentle-touch response; conversely, expression of a WT brv1 transcript in class III da neurons using the 19-12-Gal4 driver functionally rescued the touch sensitivity in the brv1 LOF larvae (Figures 1A and 1B).
The functional requirement of Brv1 in class III da neurons was studied in more detail by examining the touch responses of class III da neurons using GCaMP6, a genetically encoded Ca 2+ indicator.
In response to a 40-mm touch displacement lasting 300 ms, an increased intracellular Ca 2+ signal in class III da neurons was recorded in WT larvae.
In contrast, the Ca 2+ response was reduced by targeting brv1 RNAi in class III da neurons.

Moreover, the Ca 2+ signal response to touch stimuli in class III neurons of brv1 STOP larvae was dramatically reduced, but the defect was rescued by class III neuron expression of Brv1 (Figures 1C,1D,and S1E).

To test whether Brv1 is expressed in class III da neurons, we used an antibody generated against the C terminus of the Brv1 protein to identify Brv1, and class III da neurons were labeled with 19-12-Gal4-driven expression of UAS-mCD8-GFP.
Immunostaining of the larval body wall identified Brv1 expression in class III da neurons (Figures 1E and S1F), whereas no immunofluorescence was evident in brv1 STOP larvae (Figure S1F).
Altogether, these results demonstrate that Brv1 is required for gentle-touch sensation, likely functioning via class III da neurons in Drosophila larvae.

Brv1 Is a Pore-Forming Subunit in a Cation Channel Several mechanosensors, such as NOMPC for gentle touch and dPIEZO for mechanical nociception, have been shown to act as mechanosensitive ion channels (Kim et al., 2012;Yan et al., 2013).
We therefore set out to determine whether Brv1 forms ion channels.

We cloned full-length brv1 from third-instar larvae into the pIRES2-EGFP vector for heterologous expression in HEK293T cells and assessed the channel activity of Brv1 using electrophysiological recordings.

We found that Brv1-transfected cells, but not vector-transfected cells, displayed an outwardly rectifying current-voltage (I-V) relationship in whole-cell recording at holding potentials ranging from À100 to +100 mV (Figure 2A).
Brv1 currents were blocked by gadolinium (Gd 3+ ), whereas ruthenium red (RR) had no inhibitory effect.
Replacing Cl À in the bath solution with NaMES had no effects on the current amplitude, suggesting that the currents are carried by cation channels.
The ionic selectivity of Brv1 was determined by recordings under asymmetric buffer conditions in which the external Na + in the bath solution was replaced with various cat-ions (Figure 2B).

Reversal-potential measurements revealed that the Brv1 channel is permeable to both monovalent and divalent cations, with a relative permeability of K + > Cs + z Na + z Ca 2+ > N-methyl-D-glucamine (NMDG) (Figure 2C).
Altogether, these results demonstrate that Brv1 forms a cation channel.
Next, we determined the single-channel activity in Brv1transfected HEK293T cells in the outside-out excised patch configuration.

The spontaneous openings of Brv1 displayed an outwardly rectifying feature with outward single-channel conductance (65 ± 8 pS) that was $1.5-fold that of the inward conductance (42 ± 5 pS) (Figures 2D and 2E), whereas no current was detectable in excised patches from vector-transfected cells.

Previous structural-functional studies have shown that mutations of negatively charged residues surrounding putative pore region modify the properties of cation channels (Kang et al., 2010;Yan et al., 2013).

A pore-forming architecture of TRPP channels has been indicated by the recently resolved structure of TRPP2, in which transmembrane segments S5-S6 and the intervening pore loops contribute four individual subunits to form an ion-conducting pore (Shen et al., 2016).
Alignment of the Brv1 protein sequence to TRPP2s identified two negatively charged residues, Asp552 and Glu558, located in a predicted pore helix of Brv1 (Figure 2F).

We found that alanine substitution of Asp552 (D552A) or Glu558 (E558A) drastically reduced the (legend continued on next page) channel activity in whole-cell recordings and resulted in altered I-V curves of the spontaneously activated Brv1 channel (Figure 2G), thus providing further evidence that Brv1 forms an ion channel.

div.head: Brv1 Channel Is Activated by Stretch Stimuli

p.s: To test whether the Brv1 channel can be activated by mechanical forces, we recorded single-channel Brv1 currents in response to mechanical stimuli in the outside-out excised patch configuration.
The membrane was stretched by applying pulsed negative pressure through the recording pipette.
Brv1 was rapidly activated by the stimuli, but recordings from vector-transfected cells showed no response (Figure 3A).
The amplitude of the mechanical current depended on the stimulus strength, showing a progressive increase with gradually increased stretch (Figure 3B).
The kinetics of current activation was rapid with a short time constant (t activation), and this decreased with increasing stimulus strength (Figures 3C and 3D).
These results suggest that the underlying transduction of Brv1 is mechanically gated.
A stimulus-strength dependency was also found for the current adaptation kinetics of the Brv1 channel (Figure 3E).
The adaptation rate, which is estimated from the time constant (t adaptation) for the current decay from the peak amplitude, was accelerated from 120 ± 25 ms at À50 mmHg to 78 ± 12 ms at À80 mmHg.

However, repetitive stimulation of Brv1 at 1 s intervals elicited mechanical currents with similar amplitude, indicating that under such conditions, these currents did not desensitize (Figures 3F and 3G).
We then examined the responsiveness of Brv1 first to an adapting stimulus and then to a test stimulus.
We found that Brv1 adapted to the initial stimulus and responded to additional stimuli with an amplitude comparable to that of the initial stimulus (Figures 3H and 3I).

In addition, we found that the singlechannel current amplitude of Brv1 activated by negative pressure was similar to that of the spontaneously activated channels (Figures 2D, 2E, 3J, and 3K), although the stretch-activated Brv1 currents exhibited faster gating kinetics featuring flickering activity of the channel.

Mechanical activation of the Brv1 channel was independent of the direction of membrane deformation, because negative pressure in the inside-out excised patch configuration, which causes membrane curvature opposing that of the outside-out configuration, activated Brv1 channels (Figures 3L and 3M).

To test whether Brv1 is sufficient to form channels by itself and whether they sense mechanical stimuli, we reconstituted purified Brv1 proteins into azolectin liposomes and assessed their responses to negative pressure (Figures S2A and S2B).
Singlechannel recordings from Brv1 channels in the inside-out excised patch configuration were made from lipid blisters (Figure 3N, arrows).

Mechanical currents of the Brv1 channel were recorded in response to negative pressure, while control samples under identical conditions resulted in no detectable currents (Figures 3O,3P,S2C,and S2D).
As determined from the single-channel I-V relationship, the conductance of the Brv1 channel was 71 ± 9 pS, similar to that in Brv1-overexpressing HEK293T cells (65 ± 8 pS) (Figure 3Q).
These results provide evidence that Brv1 reconstituted into proteoliposomes undergoes mechanically induced activation.

div.head: Brv1 Alters the Response of NOMPC to Poking Stimuli

p.s: It has been reported that NOMPC is required for gentle-touch sensation in class III neurons (Yan et al., 2013).
To test a possible relationship of Brv1 and NOMPC, we co-transfected both into HEK293T cells and compared the mechanical responses with those of singly transfected cells.
Western blots and fluorescence images from fluorescent protein-tagged Brv1 and NOMPC showed normal expression of the two proteins in co-transfected cells (Figure S3).

In addition, the proteins were functional in co-transfected cells, because we determined an outwardly rectifying I-V relationship in whole-cell recordings, and the mechanical current amplitudes in response to pulsed negative pressure in excised patches were similar to those of cells transfected with Brv1 or NOMPC alone (Figures 4A-4C).
We then tested the effect of a poking stimulus delivered to the cell surface via a glass pipette driven by a piezoelectric actuator during a whole-cell recording.
We found that both vector-and Brv1-transfected cells showed no response to piezoelectric-driven displacements of up to 4 mm.

In contrast, NOMPC-transfected and co-transfected cells showed rapid poke-activated currents that increased gradually with incremental movement of the pipette, but a higher amplitude of mechanical current was recorded in co-transfected cells (14.1 ± 3.3 pA/pF) than in NOMPC-transfected cells (6.9 ± 2.1 pA/ pF) (Figures 4D and 4E).
Interestingly, 90% of the poke-induced NOMPC currents adapted within 1-2 ms, and the t adaptation of the poke currents recorded in co-transfected cells was prolonged to 100 ms (Figure 4F).
In addition, 50% of the poke currents in co-transfected cells did not decay until the stimulation was released (Figure 4G).
These results suggested that Brv1 affects the mechanical response of NOMPC.
The foundational observation here is that Brv1, a member of the TRPP subfamily, is required for Drosophila larvae to sense gentle touch.

In this study, we electrophysiologically characterized Brv1 as a pore-forming subunit of a cation channel that is activated in (M) Dose-dependent curves of pressure-induced currents recorded from inside-out patches in Brv1-transfected cells (black circles) or vector-transfected cells (red triangles).
(N) Image of Brv1-reconstituted liposomes.
The arrow indicates the membrane blisters used for patch clamp.
(O) Sample traces of reconstituted Brv1 currents recorded from an inside-out patch (held at À20 mV) in response to 500-ms pulses of negative pressure from À30 to À70 mmHg.
(P) Dose-dependent curve of pressure-induced currents recorded in the Brv1-reconstituted liposome.
(Q) I-V relationship of the average single-channel amplitude of pressure-induced Brv1 activation.
Data are represented as mean ± SEM, n = 10.
response to stretch, suggesting the direct role of Brv1 as a mechanosensitive channel in the touch response.
Brv1 is characterized as distinct from other mechanosensitive ion channels, such as NOMPC.
NOMPC functioned as a Drosophila touch sensor in response to multiple mechanical forces, including stretching and poking, while Brv1 was insensitive to poking.
Touch is a complex sense comprising diverse modalities.
A diverse array of specialized mechanoreceptors is involved in detecting a range of mechanical stimuli, including light brush, stretch, vibration, deflection of hair, and pressure.
For example, slowly adapting type 2 (SA2) afferents, which innervate Ruffini cylinders, are primarily sensitive to skin stretch (Birznieks et al., 2009).
The kinds of forces experienced during object manipulation activate SA2 stretch-sensitive afferents, which contribute to touch sensation such as grip control (Saal and Bensmaia, 2014).
So it may not be a surprise that Brv1 acts as a stretch-sensitive channel to mediate touch sensation.
The distinctions in the detection of variable forces may offer the first hints of differences in the activation mechanisms between Brv1 and NOMPC.
NOMPC has been suggested to adopt a tether gating mechanism by which the N-terminal ankyrin repeats form a tether linking the channel and the microtubules to convey force (Zhang et al., 2015).
The finding that Brv1 was mechanically gated in the liposome suggests that mechanical force is transmitted directly to the Brv1 channel through lateral membrane tension.
However, detailed structural information would be needed to elucidate the gating mechanism of Brv1 in touch sensation.

NOMPC is also recognized as required for gentle-touch sensation in class III neurons (Yan et al., 2013), which raises the questions of whether Brv1 and NOMPC work together to mediate touch sensation and how they are required for responding to gentle touch.
We found that co-expression of Brv1 and NOMPC in HEK293T cells led to increased amplitude and delayed adaptation of the poke current compared to NOMPC expression alone.

Extracellular recordings from class III neurons in abdominal segments of larval fillets has revealed that touching the body wall induces a burst of action potentials, which adapt with a time constant of $150 ms, but heterologous expression of NOMPC in S2 cells reveals that the poking currents adapt quickly, within 2 ms (Yan et al., 2013).
Brv1 might act as an amplifier of NOMPC in response to poking, thus enhancing the excitability of class III da neurons in the touch response.
A similar mechanism, by which TRPP2 inhibits the stretch-activated ion channels in vascular smooth muscle cells to regulate pressure sensing, has been reported (Sharif-Naeini et al., 2009).
These data suggest double roles of Brv1 in touch sensation: the direct role as a mechanosensitive channel and perhaps the indirect role as a modulator for the NOMPC channel.

This may partially explain why Brv1 or NOMPC LOF mutants cause severe defects in the behavioral response; however, the comprehensive role of Brv1 in touch sensation and the underlying molecular mechanisms need to be resolved in the future.

42748), and UAS-mCD8-GFP (stock no.
5137) were from the (A) Whole-cell I-V relationships of recorded in HEK293T cells transfected with Brv1 (red triangles), NOMPC (green squares), and Brv1+ NOMPC (blue circles).
The currents were evoked by 500-ms potential pulses from À100 to 100 mV in +20-mV increments.
(B) Currents of an outside-out patch (held at À80 mV) recorded from Brv1-, NOMPC-, or Brv1+NOMPC-transfected cells in response to À60 mmHg of negative pressure.

(C) Dose-dependent curves of pressure-induced currents recorded from outside-out patches in Brv1-transfected cells (black circles), NOMPCtransfected cells (green squares), or Brv1+ NOMPC-transfected cells (red triangles).

Bloomington Drosophila Stock Center, Indiana University.
brv1 L563 > STOP was provided by C. Zuker at Columbia University.
brv1 NP4486 was provided by Yi Rao at Peking University.
19-12-Gal4 was from Yuh Nung Jan at University of California, San Francisco (UCSF).

div.head: Generation of the brv1 DEL Fly

p.s: The brv1 DEL mutant was generated via CRISPR/Cas9 as described previously (Ren et al., 2013).

Single guide RNA (sgRNA) of 5 0 -AAAAGCACCGAC TCGGTGCCACTTTTTCAAGTTGATA-3 0 and 5 0 -ACGGACTAGCCTTATTTTAA CTTGCTATTTCTAGCTCTAAAAC-3 0 was used to induce the 276-bp deletion spanning positions 336 and 612 relative to the start codon, which resulted in the deletion of 92 amino acids (112-204) within the two putative transmembrane helixes predicted by the TMHMM program (Figure S1A).
Fly embryo microinjections were conducted by the Drosophila Core Facility, Institute of Biochemistry and Cell Biology, Chinese Academy of Sciences.
The deletion was confirmed by sequence analysis (Figure S1B).

Molecular Cloning and Mutagenesis brv1 cDNA was cloned from the total RNA of third-instar larvae by RT-PCR using the forward primer 5 0 -ATGGCGAAGAAGTTTAGTAAC-3 0 and reverse primer 5 0 -TCAGTCCTCCTCAGTCTCTGG-3 0 and then was inserted into the pUAST-attB vector.
The larval behavioral response to gentle touch was performed as described previously (Kernan et al., 1994).

Third-instar larvae were touched with an eyelash at one side of the thoracic segments, and the behavioral responses were scored as follows: 0, no response; 1, pause; 2, recoil; 3, single reverse contractile wave; and 4, multiple reverse contractions.
Animals were raised at 25 C in an incubator with 12 hr light/dark cycles and humidity control (Darwin Chamber).
The third-instar larvae were washed twice with PBS and transferred to a 30-mm agar plate.
The larvae were gently touched with an eyelash at one side of the thoracic segments, and the behavioral responses were scored.
Typically, the larvae would stop, contract the head, and then turn to one side or begin reverse locomotion in response to the touch with an eyelash.
Larvae that did not respond to touch were scored 0. A score of 1 was given to those larvae that paused or hesitated.

Those that retracted their heads or recoiled were scored as 2, those that retracted with a single wave were scored as 3, and those that retracted and moved in the opposite direction were scored 4. Each larva was touched and scored five times, and the values were summed as the final score.
Ca 2+ signals induced by mechanical stimulation were measured as described previously (Yan et al., 2013).
The genetically encoded Ca 2+ indicator GCaMP6 was expressed in class III da neurons under the control of 19-12-Gal4 drivers for the Ca 2+ response.
Third-instar larvae were dissected in hemolymph-like solution for fillet preparations.
Real-time fluorescent signals of GCaMP6 and red fluorescent proteins (as controls) were acquired using an Olympus FV1000 confocal laser scanning microscope.
The GCaMP6 fluorescence displayed a significant increase upon touch stimulation, whereas red fluorescent proteins showed no change in fluorescence when the same stimulus was applied.
F0 is the average GCaMP6 signal from the first 5 s before stimulation, and DF/F0 was calculated for each data point.
Immunostaining of Drosophila larvae was performed as described previously (Yan et al., 2013).

Third-instar larvae were dissected in PBS, fixed in paraformaldehyde solution for 20 min, and exposed to the primary antibody overnight at 4 C and then the secondary antibody for 2 hr at room temperature.

The Brv1 primary antibody was generated by the affinity purification of the antiserum obtained from a rabbit after injection of a peptide containing 14 amino acids (IDKDLEQMKYRERI) located at the C terminus of Brv1 (antibody service, GenScript).
The secondary antibody was red fluorescence-conjugated anti-rabbit immunoglobulin G (IgG) from Abcam.
Images were acquired on an Olympus FV1000 confocal laser scanning microscope.
Cell Culture and Transfection HEK293 cells were from the ATCC (RRID: CVCL_0063) and grown in DMEM supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (Gibco) at 37 C with 5% CO 2 .
Cells were plated onto poly-D-lysine-coated 8-mm round glass coverslips for electrophysiological analysis.
The Brv1 construct was transfected into HEK293T cells using Lipofectamine 2000 (Invitrogen).
Drosophila S2 cells were co-transfected with the pUAST-Brv1 construct and pActin-Gal4.
A FLAG tag was added to the N terminus for Brv1 protein purification.
After 48 hr, cells were harvested and homogenized in nonyl phenoxypolyethoxylethanol (NP-40) buffer (150 mM NaCl, 50 mM Tris-HCl [pH 7.5], 1% NP-40, and protease inhibitor cocktail; Roche).
Then, the lysate was shaken for 30 min and centrifuged for 15 min at 12,000 g to remove the precipitate.
The supernatant was incubated with anti-FLAG agarose affinity gel (Sigma) at 4 C overnight.
Then, the beads were washed with wash buffer (150 mM NaCl, 50 mM Tris-HCl [pH 7.5], 0.4% NP-40, and protease inhibitor cocktail).

Brv1 proteins were eluted with a buffer composed of 100 mM NaCl, 100 mM glycine (pH 3.0), 0.05% NP-40, and protease inhibitor cocktail and were neutralized with a buffer composed of 500 mM glycine (pH 8.0), 100 mM NaCl, 0.05% NP-40, and protease inhibitor cocktail.
The protein complex was purified using gel filtration chromatography on an Amersham Pharmacia A ¨KTApurifier.
Reconstitution was performed as described previously (Ha ¨se et al., 1995;Sukharev, 2002).
Azolectin (Avanti Polar Lipids) dissolved in chloroform was shell-dried under argon.
The lipid film was resuspended, and lipid vesicles were formed by bath sonication to near-clarity.
Brv1 protein was then added to the lipid vesicles at a protein-to-lipid mass ratio of 1:100 for reconstitution.
Detergent was removed by dialysis against 2 3 1,000 mL of buffer containing Calbiosorb beads (Calbiochem).
The proteoliposomes were collected by a 20-min centrifugation at 200,000 3 g (Beckman-Coulter Instruments).

The pellet was resuspended to 1.3 mg/mL in 10 mM MOPS buffer (pH 7.4) containing 5% ethylene glycol and then desiccated under vacuum overnight at 4 C. Desiccated proteoliposomes were rehydrated, and unilamellar blisters were used for patch clamping.

Brv1 and NOMPC protein were probed by incubating the blots with the rabbit anti-Brv1 primary antibody (antibody service, GenScript) or anti-FLAG primary antibody (Sigma; RRID: AB_796202) at 4 C overnight and then Alexa Fluor 680-conjugated donkey anti-rabbit IgG secondary antibody (Abcam) at room temperature for 1 hr.
Proteins were detected using the 700-nm fluorescence channel of the Odyssey imaging system (LI-COR Biosciences).
Currents were recorded using an Axopatch 200B amplifier connected to a Digidata 1440A data acquisition system (Axon Instruments).
Patch electrodes were pulled from borosilicate capillaries (Sutter Instruments) on a micropipette puller (P-97, Sutter Instruments).
Electrodes with resistances of 3.5-4.5
MU were used.
All experiments were performed at room temperature.

For recordings from HEK293T cells, the internal buffer (intracellular) consisted of 150 mM CsCl, 10 mM HEPES, 5 mM EGTA, 1 mM CaCl 2 , and 1 mM MgCl 2 (pH adjusted to 7.3 with CsOH), and the external buffer (extracellular) consisted of 145 mM NaCl, 5 mM KCl, 1 mM MgCl 2 , 5 mM EGTA, 10 mM HEPES, and 1 mM CaCl 2 , (pH adjusted to 7.3 with NaOH).
For recordings from proteoliposomes, both pipette and bath buffer consisted of 150 mM KCl, 10 mM HEPES, 1 mM CaCl 2 , and 1 mM MgCl 2 (pH adjusted to 7.3 with KOH).
For the ion-selectivity experiments, external Na + was replaced with K + or Ca 2+ or NMDG.
To estimate the relative permeability ratio of monovalent cations to Cs + , the following equation derived from the Goldman-Hodgkin-Katz model was used (Hille, 2001)
The poking stimuli were delivered using a fire-polished glass pipette (tip diameter of 1-2 mm) positioned with a micromanipulator.
Movement of the probe toward the cells was driven by a Clampex-controlled piezoelectric actuator (Physik Instrument).
For Ca 2+ imaging, a 40-mm movement of the glass pipette lasting 300 ms was applied.
For recordings from HEK293T cells, a series of 1-mm movements of the glass pipette were applied for 500 ms.

For outside-out and inside-out excised patch recordings, membrane patches were stimulated by negative pressure through the recording electrode using a high-speed pressure clamp (HSPC, ALA Scientific).
Timing and intensity of the pressure were controlled by the signals generated from Clampex.
All data were analyzed using GraphPad Prism.
Each data point was plotted as mean ± SEM.
For touch behavioral assay, n = 20 larvae per group.
For Ca 2+ imaging, n = 15 cells from 5 larvae per group.
For electrophysiology, n = 10 recordings.
Supplemental Information includes three figures and can be found with this article online at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.celrep.2018.03.041.
Figure 1.

Brv1 Is Essential for Class III da Neurons of Larvae to Sense Gentle Touch (A) Behavioral response cores of wild-type (WT Ctrl), brv1 LOF mutant (brv1 STOP and brv1 DEL ), brv1 rescue (brv1 STOP rescue and brv1 DEL rescue), brv1 knockdown (class III RNAi brv1), and control (class III RNAi Ctrl) larvae in response to gentle touch (mean ± SEM, n = 20).
The score is the sum of 5 tests for each sample.
The scores for the response are as follows: 0, no response; 1, pause; 2, recoil; 3, single reverse contractile wave; and 4, multiple reverse contractions.
(B) Percentage of each scored response in larvae of the indicated genotype.
(C) Representative Ca 2+ response traces of class III da neurons in WT (red), brv1 RNAi (green), brv1 STOP (blue), and brv1 STOP rescue (gray) larvae.
The arrowhead indicates stimulus onset (40-mm displacement for 300 ms).
(D) Summary of Ca 2+ responses of class III da neurons with different genotypes (mean ± SEM, total of 15 cells from 5 larvae).
(E) Immunostaining of Brv1 in class III da neurons labeled with class III-neuron-specific 19-12-Gal4-driven GFP.
Scale bar, 30 mm.
The enlarged view shows the spike-like protrusion (indicated by an arrow), which is the hallmark of class III neurons.
Genotypes are as follows.
WT control: w 1118 .
brv1 STOP : brv1 L563 > STOP .
brv1 DEL : brv1 112-204 > DEL .
brv1 STOP rescue: brv1 L563 > STOP /UAS-Brv1; 19-21-GAL4/+.
brv1 DEL rescue: brv1 112-204 > DEL /UAS-Brv1; 19-21-GAL4/+.
RNAi control: w 1118 , UAS-brv1-RNAi.
Class III brv1 RNAi: 19-12-GAL4, UAS-brv1-RNAi.

Figure 2. Brv1 Heterologously Expressed in HEK293T Cells Forms Cation Channels (A) Whole-cell I-V relationships of spontaneously activated Brv1 channels (red triangles), Brv1 treated with 100 mM gadolinium (Gd 3+ , green circles) or 50 mM ruthenium red (RR, blue triangles), or Brv1 bathing in NaMES solution (brown diamonds).
Vector-transfected HEK293T served as control (black squares).
The currents were evoked by 500-ms pulses from À100 to 100 mV in 20-mV increments.
(B) I-V relationships of Brv1 channel currents recorded after replacing Na + in the extracellular saline solution with the indicated cation.
(C) Relative permeability of Brv1 to different cations.
The permeability ratio was estimated by average reversal-potential changes relative to a CsCl-based internal solution.
(D) Single-channel currents of spontaneously activated Brv1 channels recorded from an outsideout excise patch at indicated membrane potentials.
Dashed horizontal lines indicate the closed states.
(E) I-V relationships of the average single-channel amplitude of Brv1-transfected cells (black circles) or vector-transfected cells (red triangles).
The slope was used to estimate conductance.
(F) Sequence alignment of the putative pore region of Brv1 and PKD homologs.
Asterisks mark negatively charged residues D552 and E558 targeted for mutagenesis.
(G) I-V curves of spontaneously activated WT Brv1 (red triangles), mutants D552A (blue circles), and E558A (green squares).
Data are represented as mean ± SEM, n = 10.

Figure 3. Brv1 Conducts Mechanical Currents (A) Currents of an outside-out patch (held at À80 mV) recorded from Brv1-or vector-transfected cells in response to 500-ms pulses of negative pressure from À40 to À80 mmHg.
(B) Dose-dependent curves of pressure-induced currents recorded from outside-out patches in Brv1-transfected cells (black circles) or vector-transfected cells (red triangles).
(C) Sample traces showing the short latency of negative pressure-induced currents.
The arrow indicates the onset of stimulus.
The activation time constant (t activation) was obtained from a single exponential fit of the negative pressure-activated currents to reach peak amplitude.
(D) Activation time constant of Brv1 is pressure dependent.
(E) Adaption time constant of Brv1 is pressure dependent.
t adaptation was obtained from a single exponential fit of the decay of negative pressure-activated currents.
(F) Sample traces of repetitive 0.5-s stimuli (À80 mmHg) at 1-s intervals between stimuli.
(G) Amplitude of pressure-activated currents in response to repetitive stimuli.
(H) Sample trace of Brv1 currents in response to a series of testing and adapting stimuli (À10 mmHg) at a 100-ms interval between the two stimuli.
(I) Amplitudes of Brv1 currents in response to serial adapting stimuli.
(J) Single-channel currents of spontaneously activated (0 mmHg) or negative pressure-activated (À80 mmHg) Brv1 channels.
Multiple openings (O1-O3) are shown in histogram analysis.
O, open; C, closed.
The dashed horizontal line indicates the closed state.
Solid horizontal lines indicate the open state.(K)
Single-channel current amplitude of spontaneously activated (spon.
curr.) and negative pressure-activated (mech.
curr.)
Brv1 channels.
(L) Sample currents of an inside-out excised patch (held at À80 mV) recorded from Brv1-or vector-transfected cells in response to 500-ms pulses of negative pressure from À40 to À80 mmHg.
Figure 4. Co-expression of Brv1 Alters Poke-Induced NOMPC Currents
(E) Co-expression of Brv1 increases the amplitude of poke-induced NOMPC current.
(F) Co-expression of Brv1 prolongs the adaption time constant of NOMPC.
t adaptation was obtained from a single exponential fit of the decay of poke-activated currents.
(G) Co-expression of Brv1 decreases the adaption of poke-induced NOMPC current.
Data are represented as mean ± SEM, n = 10.
